identificationModule.briefTitle: Robotic Versus Thoracolaparoscopic Esophagectomy for Esophageal Cancer
identificationModule.officialTitle: Robotic Versus Thoracolaparoscopic Esophagectomy for Carcinoma Esophagus: a Prospective Comparative Study

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Esophageal cancer is a debilitating condition. The treatment involved is complex requiring a combination of chemotherapy and surgery in most cases. Complete removal of the tumor and the adjacent lymph nodes is of utmost importance in improving the survival. Lymph node yield following surgery helps in proper staging of the disease and is an important prognosticating variable. It is hypothesized that the lymph node yield following robotic esophagectomy is higher than that following thoracolaparoscopic esophagectomy. The study aims to compare the short term oncological outcomes following robotic esophagectomy and thoracolaparoscopic esophagectomy for carcinoma esophagus.

armGroups.label: Robotic esophagectomy
armGroups.description: Esophagectomy performed for esophageal cancer using the da Vinci robotic surgical system

armGroups.label: Thoracolaparoscopic esophagectomy
armGroups.description: Esophagectomy performed for esophageal cancer using conventional thoracoscopic and laparoscopic techniques

interventions.name: Robotic esophagectomy
interventions.description: Removal of the esophagus and its draining lymph nodes using robotic surgical instruments

interventions.name: Thoracolaparoscopic esophagectomy
interventions.description: Removal of the esophagus and its draining lymph nodes using conventional thoracoscopic and laparoscopic techniques

primaryOutcomes.description: Total number of lymph nodes harvested

secondaryOutcomes.description: The proximal, distal and circumferential surgical margins will be assessed by pathological evaluation for the presence of tumor and will be assigned an "R" category as defined by the College of American Pathologists. R0 would indicate no evidence of residual tumor. Presence of microscopic tumor at margins would be designated as R1 whereas the presence of macroscopically visible tumor at margins would be designated as R2.
Intraoperative and post operative adverse events assessed by Clavien Dindo classification system
Duration of stay in ICU following surgery
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During index admission or within 30 days after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: Length of stay in hospital following surgery
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During index admission or re admission within 30 days
During index admission or within 90 days following surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: Time taken to complete the surgical procedure recorded in minutes
Amount of blood lost during and within 24 hours of surgery
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During surgery and up to 24 hours after index surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: Need for conversion of the procedure to open or other alternate technique

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Resectable esophageal carcinoma, either squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma in the middle or lower part the esophagus

Exclusion Criteria:

* American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) class 4 and above
* Esophagectomy for other non-malignant conditions
